page.title: Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

revisions.rev:
{{About|the domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests|international reactions|International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} <!--please do not add "cleanup" tag to this article. as long as it is tagged "current" tag, that is enough to alert a reader/editor that the article may not be fully flushed. Instead, tag specific sections you feel need urgent attention.-->
There have been numerous '''domestic responses to the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]'''. Opposition parties, activists and religious bodies have been staunchly demanding [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation, with the exception of fearful Christian authorities, who called for staying away from the protests (although Christian individuals have taken part). The government has made ongoing attempts at media censorship, including briefly shutting down nearly all Internet traffic.
Mubarak has made some initial changes to quell dissent, including dissolving his government, and appointing military figure and former head of Egypt's intelligence service [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, Ahmed Shafiq, to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|author=Shadid, Anthony; Kirpatrick, David D. |title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=2011-01-31|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-01-30}}</ref>
{{Politics of Egypt}}
==Government== === Before Mubarak's resignation === On 29 January, the head of the [[Shura Council|Egyptian Shura Council]]'s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, and also a part of the ruling party, said he does not believe the protests have ended yet.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}}Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 January 2011. ~2:00</ref>
On 29 January, in response to the previous days' events, President Mubarak spoke on national television after midnight local time for the first time since the protests began. He said in his speech that despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}} Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time</ref><ref> {{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]] | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/ | title=Protesters Return to Cairo's Main Square â Egyptian President Fires His Cabinet But Refuses To Step Down | work=[[MSNBC]] | date=2011-01-29 | accessdate=2011-02-01
}} </ref> He made no offer to step down himself.<ref> {{cite news | author=Mackey, Robert | url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/latest-updates-on-protests-in-egypt/#egypts-president-to-dismiss-ministers | title=Updates on Friday's Protests in Egypt | publisher=''The Lede'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'') | date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01 }} </ref> On 29 January, Mubarak appointed [[Omar Suleiman]], head of Egyptian Intelligence, as vice president,<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}} ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 15:24 UTC, 29 January 2011</ref> and [[Ahmed Shafik]] as prime minister.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}} ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:00 UTC, 29 January 2011</ref>

* <small>On 9 February, Culture Minister [[Gaber Asfour]] resigned after one week in office citing health problems.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weaver |first=Matthew |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/09/egypt-protests-live-updates-9-february |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 9 February | News | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 9 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11 |location=London}}</ref></small>
{| style="width:70%;" class="wikitable sortable collapsible collapsed" |+ Positions in previous government that are unresolved |- ! Office ! Previous office holder<ref name="CIA-leaders" /> |- | [[Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources (Egypt)|Ministry of Petroleum]] | [[Sameh Fahmi]] |- | [[Ministry of Housing, Utilities, and Urban Communities (Egypt)|Ministry of Housing, Utilities, and Urban Communities]] | [[Ahmed Alaa E-Din Amin El-Maghrabi]] |}
On 31 January, Mubarak swore in his new cabinet in the hope that the unrest would fade. The protesters did not leave and continued to demonstrate in Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] to demand the downfall of Mubarak. The vice-president and the prime minister were already appointed.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011131132324475241.html |title=Mubarak Swears in New Cabinet â Egypt's President Appoints New Cabinet in an Attempt To Quell Ongoing Mass Street Protests Against His Rule |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> He told the new government to preserve subsidies, control inflation and provide more jobs.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113101237787481.html |title=Mubarak Orders State Subsidies â Hosni Mubarak Ordered His New PM To Preserve Subsidies, Control Inflation and Provide More Jobs|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
On 1 February, Mubarak said he never intended to run for reelection<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html |title=Defiant Mubarak Vows To Finish Term â Violence Erupts in Alexandria Shortly After Egyptian President's Announcement That He Will Not Seek Another Term|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-02-02|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> in the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|upcoming September presidential election]], though his candidacy had previously been announced by high-ranking members of his National Democratic Party<ref>{{cite web|author=El-Ghatrify, Alaa|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/211975 |title=NDP Official: President To Run for 6th Term; Gamal Mubarak Candidacy 'Delusory' |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=2010-10-21|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
In his speech, he asked parliament for reforms: {{Bquote|According to my constitutional powers, I call on parliament in both its houses to discuss amending article 76 and 77 of the constitution concerning the conditions on running for presidency of the republic and it sets specific a period for the presidential term. In order for the current parliament in both houses to be able to discuss these constitutional amendments and the legislative amendments linked to it for laws that complement the constitution and to ensure the participation of all the political forces in these discussions, I demand parliament to adhere to the word of the judiciary and its verdicts concerning the latest cases which have been legally challenged.|x|x|Hosni Mubarak|1 February 2011<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]|title=Hosni Mubarak's Speech: Full Text â Egypt President Delivers TV Address to the Nation â and Pledges To Step Down at the Next Election and Pave Way for New Leader|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/president-hosni-mubarak-egypt-speech|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-02-02|accessdate=2011-02-02|location=London}}</ref>}}
==Opposition== ===Protester demands=== [[File:A sign with with the protests demand.jpg|thumb|A sign with the protesters' omnibus demands]] Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to a number of legal and constitutional provisions which affect elections. Specifically they call for: * Amendment of Article 76 of the Constitution to make it easier for party and independent candidates to get on the presidential ballot. * Amendment of Article 77 to establish term limits for the presidency, which were removed from the Constitution in 1981. * Amendment of Article 88 to restore full judicial supervision of elections. This would help tame election fraud and vote rigging, which are common in Egyptian elections. * Amendment of Law 177 of 2005 in order to facilitate the formation of new political parties. * Amendment of Article 179: Amendments in 2007 to Article 179 included an "anti-terrorism" measure, which allows for arbitrary arrest, searches and wiretapping without warrant, and transfer of any civilian court case of the presidentâs choosing to military tribunals. Unlike the Emergency law, it is a permanent measure and not a temporary measure requiring parliamentary approval.
In the Spring 2010, Mohamed El baradei began circulating a petition in the runup to the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]] calling for [[National_Association_for_Change#Platform|7 specific reforms]]: # End the state of emergency. # Ensure full judicial supervision of elections. # Provide for domestic and international monitoring of elections. # Ensure that all candidates have sufficient access to the media, particularly during the presidential election campaign. # Allow Egyptians abroad to vote through embassies and consulates. # Work toward a political system built on democracy and social justice. # Provide the right to nomination for political office without obstacles, in accordance with Egyptâs obligations under the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights; limit the president to two terms. # Allow voting by national identification card. These measures will require [[National_Association_for_Change#Goals|amending articles 76, 77, and 88 of the Constitution]] as soon as possible.<ref name="egyptelections">{{cite web|first=Matthew|url=http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/01/constitutional-and-legal-framework|title=Constitutional and Legal Framework|work=[[Carnegie Endowment]] |location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
===Muslim Brotherhood=== [[File:Leave in several languages.png|150px|thumb|"Leave" in several languages.]] In response to 25 January events, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said: "Egypt is undergoing important events where the Egyptian people started a movement in Cairo and other cities in the country expressing their anger and denouncing the practices and violations by the system." Following Mubarak's speech,{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=which speech?}} the brotherhood issued a statement reiterating demands for Mubarak's resignation and saying it was time for the military to intervene.<ref>{{dead link|date=January 2011|reason=ARCHIVE version is dead link. webcitation.org fails on various platforms (if it works at all)}}{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | title=Live: Egypt Unrest | accessdate=2011-01-29 | date=2011-01-28 | work=[[BBC News]] | archivedate=2011-01-29 | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE | quote=Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country.}}{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=who is speaking? an editorial in the media? someone is quoted?}}</ref> The brotherhood also said it would not be nominating a new president.
On 30 January, it called for all opposition groups to unite while blaming Mubarak for the situation. The brotherhood supports Mohammed ElBaradei's [[National Association for Change]].<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} On 30 January, ''The Guardian'' reported that ElBaradei has been mandated by the brotherhood and four other opposition groups to negotiate an interim "national salvation government."<ref>{{cite news|author=Matthew Weaver, Matthew; Bowcott, Owen (2:26 pm update)|title=Egypt Protests â As They Happened â â¢ Mohamed ElBaradei Addresses Protesters in Tahrir Square â â¢ Thousands of Protesters Have Returned to the Streets â â¢ ''Al-Jazeera'' Has Been Taken Off Air in Egypt â â¢ Vigilante Groups Formed To Protect Neighbourhoods|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/30/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-33|accessdate=2011-01-30|publisher=[[Blog]] at ''[[The Guardian]]''|date=2011-02-01|location=London}}</ref> There were also demands by the brotherhood that Mubarak step down.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110130-muslim-brotherhood-demands-mubarak-step-down-elections |title=The Muslim Brotherhood Demands That President Mubarak Step Down |work=[[France 24]] |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
===Mohammed ElBaradei=== [[File:ElBaredei during Friday of Anger.png|thumb|Mohammed ElBaradei during ''Friday of Anger'']] On 27 January 2011, [[Mohammed ElBaradei]] returned to Egypt amid ongoing turmoil. He declared himself ready to lead a transitional government if that was the will of the nation, saying that: "If ''[people]'' want me to lead the transition, I will not let them down".<ref>Memmot, Matt (27 January 2011). [http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/27/133275390/el-baradei-back-in-egypt-says-its-time-for-a-new-government "ElBaradei Back In Egypt; Says It's Time For A New Government"]. ''The Two-Way'' ([[blog]] on [[NPR]]). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> He called for ousting the regime, as in Tunisia.<ref name="Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidANA20110122T190139ZNYZ32/?relcontent=ZW20110127000145 |title=Egyptians Should Copy Tunisian Revolt: ElBaradi |publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via [[zawya.com]]) |date=2011-01-22 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> Subsequently, "when he joined protesters Friday after noon prayers, police fired water cannons at him and his supporters. They used batons to beat some of ElBaradei's supporters, who surrounded him to protect him."<ref>[[Staff writer]] (28 January 2011).[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/28/violent-clashes-police-break-cairo/ "Five People Killed During Protests in Egypt"]. ''[[Fox News]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> ElBaradei said he was "proud of the protesters" and proud of the military, who by 29 January were the only state force on the streets of Cairo, with police nowhere to be seen. There were numerous individual public displays of affection and respect for soldiers manning positions on the streets.<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. TV report. 29 January 2011. 12.00 GMT.{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}}</ref> He urged the US to end the "life support to the dictator" and that "It is better for President Obama not to appear that he is the last one to say to President Mubarak, 'It's time for you to go.'"<ref>{{cite news|author=Stewart, Phil; Morgan, David|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/us-egypt-usa-elbaradei-idUSTRE70T30920110130?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews |title=ElBaradei Urges U.S. To Abandon Mubarak |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
ElBaradei has also stated that "the people (of Egypt) want the regime to fall". In response to the appointment of [[Omar Suleiman]] as the new Vice President of Egypt, ElBaradei stated that it was a "hopeless, desperate attempt by Mubarak to stay in power, I think it is loud and clear...that Mubarak has to leave today". Additionally, he restated the position that when Egypt does become a democratic nation and that "there is no reason to believe that a democracy in Egypt would not lead to a better relationship with the US based on respect and equity."<ref>[[Fareed Zakaria|Zakaria, Fareed]] (30 January 2011). [http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2011/01/30/gps.elbaradei.intv.cnn?iref=allsearch "ElBaradei: Egypt's Mubarak Must Leave"] (video; requires [[Adobe Flash]]). ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'' (via ''[[CNN]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
As of 30 January, the [[6 April Youth Movement]], the [[We Are All Khaled Said Movement]], the [[National Association for Change]], the [[25 January Movement]] and [[Kefaya]] â the main organizers of the protests â had all asked ElBaradei to act in the country's internal affairs and foreign affairs in the transitional phase, and for the formation of a temporary national salvation{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=odd to the ear in english. perhaps too literal translation? (sorry don't have arabic skills). would more expect "temporary national government" or "transitional national government"}}<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs byline (or in absence of byline, "staff writer" dropped into "author" field).}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2011/01/110130_egypt_demo_new.shtml|title=Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ´ ÙØ¯ÙØ¹ Ø¨ØªØ¹Ø²ÙØ²Ø§Øª Ø§Ø¶Ø§ÙÙØ© ÙØ·Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø§Øª Ø­Ø±Ø¨ÙØ© ØªØ­ÙÙ ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ ØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø©|trans_title=''Army Sends Additional Military Aircraft Reinforcements Flying over Protesters in Cairo''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[BBC Arabic]]|date=2011-01-30|accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
===Yusuf al-Qaradawi===
Having returned after 30 years of exile from his native country of Egypt, [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] in [[Tahrir Square]] proclaimed,"Egyptian people are like the genie who came out of the lamp and who have been in prison for 30 years" and, âWe are not going back in until all our demands are met.â
He also made assuring statements about the [[Copts|Coptic]] minority:
<blockquote>The regime planted sectarianism here â¦ in Tahrir Muslims and Christians joined hands for a better Egypt</blockquote>
He also made demands including the dissolution of the current cabinet, release of thousands of political prisoners, end of the infamous state security services, and the end of the [[Gaza blockade]].
After the sermon thousands of protesters settled into prayer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses/ |title=Egypt revolution unfinished, Qaradawi tells Tahrir masses |publisher=Csmonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
===Political reactions=== Judges, who were particularly vocal about the independence of the judiciary during the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|2005 Egyptian presidential election]] also joined talks about the interim government.<ref name="Egypt's opposition discusses interim government">{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-opposition-discusses-interim-government|title=Egypt's Opposition Discusses Interim Government|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-30|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
Local [[Sheikh]]s reportedly took control of the remote community [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] after the protests began to escalate, they reportedly put the community on lockdown after a nearby town "was torched".<ref name="Mistry">{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|publisher=''[[St. Albans Review]]'' (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=2011-01-31|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
===Others=== ;Political individuals [[Amr Moussa]], the head of the [[Arab League]] and an Egyptian citizen, said he would consider a decision to run in the upcoming [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|2011 presidential election]].<ref>[[Staff writer]] (2 February 2011). [http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=206306 "Amr Moussa Says He Will Consider Seeking Egypt Presidency"]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
Former UN Secretary-General [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]] expressed concern over a transitional period that could not be effective if it was forced too early. In that vein, he said the Mubarak should not leave immediately and that direct negotiations could bring about a solution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110203-interview-boutros-boutros-ghali-egypt-former-egyptian-foreign-minister-ex-un-secretary-general-protests-cairo-mubarak |title=Boutros Boutros-Ghali, former Egyptian Foreign Minister |publisher=France24 |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> He also warned of an economic collapse saying that "the Egyptian public is unaware of the impact such a crisis will have over the next few months. You can't effect a transition in 24 hours and at the same time avert the risk of uncontrollable chaos."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-unrest-might-cause-economic-collapse-Boutros-Ghali/Article1-658848.aspx |title=Egypt unrest might cause economic collapse: Boutros Ghali |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2011-02-05 |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
;Apolitical individuals [[Amr Khaled]], a [[Muslim]] [[Televangelism|televangelist]], activist and preacher, said the future of Egypt needs a government to listen to the young people and respect them.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE70R1K020110128|title=Ø§ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¹ÙØ© Ø§ÙÙ ØµØ±Ù Ø¹Ù Ø±Ù Ø®Ø§ÙØ¯ ÙØªÙØ¬Ù Ø§ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø©|trans_title= ''Egyptian Preacher Amr Khaled, Heading to Cairo''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=2011-01-28|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> [[Image:ArabicGoOnYoungPeopleBanner.jpg|thumb|widthpx|A large banner in Cairo's Tahrir Square on 1 February: "Go On, Young People!"]]
On 31 January, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that Egyptian-born actor [[Omar Sharif]] called for Mubarak to step down.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8292533/Egypt-in-crisis-Lawrence-of-Arabia-star-Omar-Sharif-calls-for-president-to-go.html|date=2011-01-31|title=Egypt in Crisis: 'Lawrence of Arabia' Star Omar Sharif Calls for President To Go â Film Legend Omar Sharif Has Joined Growing for Hosni Mubarak, Egypt's President, To Step Down, Saying He Had Failed To Improve the Standard of Living for Ordinary People and That 30 Years in Power Was Enough|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2011-02-01|location=London}}</ref>
[[Ahmed Zewail]], an Egyptian-American scientist and the winner of the 1999 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]], said that Egypt cannot resolve the crisis without changing the system. He offered a proposal of four items to remove Egypt from the crisis and enter a new era. He said that reason for this proposal is his sense of duty towards Egypt and its youth.<ref>{{verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason= is this "al masdar" mainstream media? it seemingly has no Wikipedia article. also, needs byline added (or addition of "staff writer" if no byline).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.almasdaronline.com/index.php?page=news&article-section=37&news_id=15627|title=Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ ØµØ±Ù Ø£Ø­Ù Ø¯ Ø²ÙÙÙ ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ø¥ÙÙ ØªØºÙÙØ± Ø§ÙÙØ¸Ø§Ù ÙÙ Ù ØµØ± ÙØ¹Ù Ø±Ù Ù ÙØ³Ù ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù ÙØ¥ØµÙØ§Ø­ Ø­ÙÙÙÙ|trans_title=''Egyptian Scientist Ahmed Zewail Calls for Regime Change in Egypt, Amr Moussa Calls for Real Reform''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=|work=[[Al Masdar]]|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
===Apolitical=== On 27 January, the [[Egyptian Football Association]] announced that all [[Egyptian League]] games would be suspended in order to keep "clubs from congregating." Yet the [[fan club]]s, know as "[[ultras]]," organised neighbourhood committees to provide security amidst looting and also to confront the police. The move was read by CNN as allowing for "the poor, the disenfranchised, and the mass of young people" to take part in the protests. One [[sports writer]] said that "The involvement of organised soccer fans in Egypt's anti-government protests constitutes every Arab government's worst nightmare. Soccer, alongside Islam, offers a rare platform in the Middle East, a region populated by authoritarian regimes that control all public spaces, for the venting of pent-up anger and frustration." The move was also followed by a Libyan government directive to the [[Libyan Football Federation]] to cancel matches for the "foreseeable future" on concern over the unrest spreading.<ref>Zirin, Dave ([[essay]]) (31 January 2011). [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/writers/dave_zirin/01/31/egypt.soccer/index.html#ixzz1D04PJmYT "Soccer Clubs Central to Ending Egypt's 'Dictatorship of Fear'"]. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''. Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref>
==Religious institutions==
Many of [[Al-Azhar Mosque|Al-Azhar Imams]] joined the protesters on 30 January all over the country.<ref>{{verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason=what are credentials of "elaph publisher". seemingly has no Wikipedia article. also, citation needs byline (or in absence of byline, addition of "staff writer" to "author" field).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.elaph.com/Web/arts/2011/1/628400.html|title=Ø®Ø§ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØµØ§ÙÙ ÙÙÙØ¯ Ù Ø¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙ Ù ÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± |trans_title=''Khaled El Sawy Leads Demonstration in Tahrir Square''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2011-01-30|work=[[Elaph Publishing]]|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
[[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox]] Bishop Marcos of [[Shubra El-Khiema]] urged Christians not to join the demonstrations, saying that they do not know the goals of those responsible for launching the protests.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs byline (or in absence of byline, "staff writer" dropped into the "author" field).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=285805&IssueID=2025|title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø³ Ø§ÙÙ Ø³ÙØ­ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ§Ø« ØªØ±ÙØ¶ Ù Ø¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ù¢Ù¥ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±.. ÙØªØ·Ø§ÙØ¨ Ø§ÙØ£ÙØ¨Ø§Ø· Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙÙ Ø´Ø§Ø±ÙØ©|trans_title=''At Three Demonstrations Christian Churches in Egypt Reject 25 January Protest; Ask Their Followers Not To Participate''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2011-01-24|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> During his weekly sermon [[Pope Shenouda III]] asked his followers to be "calm" for the second day of demonstrations during his weekly sermon.<ref>{{verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason=what are credentials of this "youm7.com" source. seemingly has no Wikipedia article. also, 1. citation needs byline (or in absence of byline, "staff writer" dropped into "author" field). also, 2. something funky about date (arabic characters in midst...seems to copy from source when copying numeric date).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.youm7.com/News.asp?NewsID=344449|title=ÙÙ Ø¹Ø¸ØªÙ Ø§ÙØ£Ø³Ø¨ÙØ¹ÙØ©.. Ø§ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¬Ù ÙØ¹ ÙÙ"Ø§ÙØªÙØ¯Ø¦Ø©"|trans_title=''In Weekly Sermon, Pope Shenouda Calls for Calm''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=Ø¬Ù Ø§Ù Ø¬Ø±Ø¬Ø³ Ø§ÙÙ Ø²Ø§Ø­Ù |date=2011-01-26|work=|publisher=[[youm7.com]]|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> On 31 January, he expressed support for Mubarak in an interview with Egyptian state television.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703439504576116222399438428.html|title=Coptic Christians Worry About Future Without Mubarak |author=Champion, Marc|date=2011-02-01|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> In spite of this, a number of young Christian activists joined the protests led by well-known Christians like member of the Wafd Party [[Raymond Lakah]]. [[Naguib Sawiris]], the head of [[Orascom Telecom]] said that the appointment of Omar Suleiman as vice president may not satisfy protestors. "I think it is not enough. It's a good step because the gentleman, Mr. Suleiman has a very good international reputation; he is from the system so he can at least ensure that the current transition to a more democratic regime can happen."<ref>Derhally, Massoud A. (30 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/sawiris-says-suleiman-appointment-may-not-be-enough-to-end-egypt-protest.html "Sawiris Says Suleiman Appointment May 'Not Be Enough' to End Egypt Protest"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> Coptic thinker{{Clarify|date=February 2011}} {{link-interwiki|en=Rafiq Habib|lang=ar|lang_title=Ø±ÙÙÙ Ø­Ø¨ÙØ¨}} condemned the position of the church but he stressed that the participation of Copts in the demonstrations are increasing day by day.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs byline (or in absence of byline, "staff writer" dropped into "author" field).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9|title=Ø§ÙÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø¨Ù ÙØ£Ù Ø¹Ù Ù Ø¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ù ØµØ±|trans_title=''Church Stays Away from Protests in Egypt''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2011-01-27|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
==Arrests== Activists reported that security agents have detained a number of protesters who were taking part in 25 January demonstration. Twenty-five people have been arrested at [[Asyut]],<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypt-govt-security-detains-protesters-cairo-and-assiut|title=Egypt Govt Security Detains Protesters in Cairo and Assiut|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> according to Gamal Eid, director of the [[Arabic Network for Human Rights Information]] (ANHRI). He also noted that security agents seized banners hoisted by the protesters.<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/> Security sources said that Asyut's police arrested approximately 50 young people the night before 25 January demonstration and confined them in Central Security trucks.<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/> An estimated 860 protesters had been arrested by the beginning of demonstrations on Tuesday.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|author=Fahim, Kareem; El-Naggar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/world/middleeast/27egypt.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&hp|title=Protesters in Egypt Defy Ban as Government Cracks Down|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
Sources at the Muslim Brotherhood said a number of the group's members had been detained in [[Mohandessin]] before heading to join 25 January demonstration.<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/> Essam al-Erian, the main spokesperson for the Muslim Brotherhood, was detained on 28 January, along with other senior Muslim Brotherhood leaders.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/20-senior-mb-members-arrested-ahead-friday-protests|title=20 Senior MB Members Arrested Ahead of Friday Protests|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
[[Ayman Nour]], the founder of the liberal opposition [[El-Ghad Party]], tweeted that his son was taken by an unmarked car. Security forces arrested ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' reporter Jack Shenker in Cairo, who secretly recorded his subsequent journey in a police van. After stopping near a government security headquarters outside the city, a policeman searched for Ayman Nour's son, however, the detainees overpowered him and escaped.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests|title=Egypt Protests: 'We Ran a Gauntlet of Officers Beating Us with Sticks'|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-26|location=London}}</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei was also reported to be under house arrest.<ref>{{cite web|author=Radia, Kirit; Khan, Huma; Marquardt, Alexander|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/egypt-clashes-escalate-nobel-laureate-house-arrest/story?id=12785851|title=President Mubarak Tells Defiant Egyptians That Government Will Resign â President Obama Says He Spoke to Mubarak and Told Him 'There Must Be Reform'|work=[[ABC News]]|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
On 31 January, six ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' journalists were arrested and their camera equipment was seized. The journalists were released later that day,<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Live Blog 31/1 â Egypt Protests (2.11 pm)|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/30/live-blog-311-egypt-protests|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=2011-01-31|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> although the equipment was reportedly not returned.
==Mediajihad: censorship and circumvention== <!--International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protest links to this section--> [[File:Timeline of Communication Shutdown during the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.jpg|thumb|Timeline of Communication Shutdown during the 2011 Egyptian Revolution]] [[Image:RadioCairoNetworkQuoteErrorUnquote.jpg|thumb|Radio Cairo DNS error.]] Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Kessler, Sarah|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|work=[[Mashable]]|date=2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which had helped protesters to spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech ''savvy'' youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media. (As one activist succinctly tweeted during the protests, "âWe use Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world.")<ref>http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/</ref>
On 27 January, it was reported on [[Twitter]] by many Egyptian and foreign reporters on the ground that the government had blocked text messaging and [[BlackBerry]] messaging services.<ref name="BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt">{{cite web|author=Rao, Leena|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/01/27/blackberry-internet-service-reportedly-blocked-in-egypt|title=BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt|work=[[Techcrunch]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> [[censorship of Twitter|Twitter was sporadically blocked]],<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx |title=Live Updates: Opposition Groups Protest on Police Day |work=[[Al-Ahram]] |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ribeiro, John |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt after Political Unrest |work=[[Computerworld]] |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Kessler, Sarah|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/ |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt As Protests Turn Violent |work=[[Mashable]] |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> then [[censorship of Facebook|Facebook]].<ref>Park, Cara (26 January 2011). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt_n_814586.html "Facebook Blocked In Egypt? Rumors Persist, But No Confirmation"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=York, Jillian C.|url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/28/egypt-an-internet-blackhole/ |title=Egypt: An Internet Black Hole |publisher=[[Global Voices Online]] |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
{{External media |video1={{YouTube|b_jRcxuemtg|Time-lapse graph of Egyptian ISPs withdrawing from the Internet}} }}
''Al Jazeera'' said its television transmission had to be switched to another frequency as its signal on [[Nilesat]] was jammed.<ref name="bloomberg1">{{cite web|author=Browning, Jonathan; Sherman, Alex|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-withdraws-from-web-blocks-phones-after-protesters-take-to-streets.html |title=Egypt Cuts Off Access to the Internet Following Street Protests |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> The network was again shut down in the country on 30 January and its bureau in Cairo was shut down.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/LAW_192612.html |title=Egypt Shuts Down ''Al Jazeera'' Operations |publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[Trade Arabia]]'') |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.al.jazeera/ | title=Egyptian Government Orders ''Al Jazeera'' Shutdown | accessdate=2011-02-01 | date=2011-01-30 | work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' said that Egyptian state media called on Egyptians to stop watching ''Al Jazeera'' claiming only they had the real story.<!--from TV, online source pending--> A statement from the network denounced the move as an attempt to "stifle and repress" the freedom of the press in Egypt and that the network would continue its coverage regardless.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113085252994161.html |title=Egypt Shuts Down ''Al Jazeera'' Bureau â Network's Licences Cancelled and Accreditation of Staff in Cairo Withdrawn by Order of Information Minister|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> On 2 February, the network asked [[Nilesat]] to restore its broadcast or face legal action.<ref>Pamuk, Humeyra (2 February 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7110P320110202 "''Al Jazeera'' Urges Egypt's Nilesat To Resume Service"]. ''[[Reuters]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' reported that [[Vodafone]] was forced by the Egyptian government to send SMS text messages to its customers. The pro-Mubarak messages characterized protesters as un-loyal to the state and that they should be confronted. The Vodafone chief executive officer [[Vittorio Colao]] also reported that the general public is still being blocked from sending SMS text messages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Browning, Jonathan|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/vodafone-ordered-to-send-egyptian-government-messages-update1-.html |title=Vodafone Says It Was Instructed To Send Pro-Mubarak Messages to Customers |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> The UK government then complained to the Egyptian government over its forcing Vodafone to send the messages.<ref>Browning, Jonathan; Penny, Thomas (4 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/vodafone-france-telecom-ordered-to-send-text-messages-in-egypt.html "UK Complains to Egypt on Ordered Vodafone Messages"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
Starting just after midnight local time on the night of 27/28 January<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off [[Internet in Egypt#2011 Internet shutdown| Internet access]]<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock">{{Verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason=what are credentials of this citation? source - "renesys" seemingly has no Wikipedia article}} {{dead link|date=February 2011|reason=webcitation.org fails on various platforms. need different archival service}} {{cite web| last =Cowie| first =James| title =Egypt Leaves the Internet|publisher =[[Renesys]]| date =| url =http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml | accessdate =2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w51j0pga |archivedate=2011-01-28|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock">{{dead link|date=February 2011|reason=webcitation.org fails on various platforms/browsers. need different archival service}} {{cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | title=With Wired Internet Locked, Egypt Looks to the Sky | date=2011-01-28 | publisher=''[[IDG|IDG News]]'' (via ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'') | url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/218064/with_wired_internet_locked_egypt_looks_to_the_sky.html |accessdate=2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w518Yu9B |archivedate=2011-01-28|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Naureen|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=''The Pomed Wire'' ([[blog]] by the [[Project on Middle East Democracy]])|date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> in an act of unprecedented<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Rhoads |first=Christopher |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703956604576110453371369740.html?mod=googlenews_ws |title=Egypt Shuts Down Internet, Cellphone Services - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> [[Internet censorship]]. About 3,500 [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) routes to Egyptian networks were shut down from about 12:10 am to 12:35 am 28 January.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> The shutdown happened within the space of a few tens of minutes, not instantaneously. According to Renesys, [[Telecom Egypt]] started shutting down at 12:12 am, [[Vodafone|Raya/Vodafone]] at 12:13 am, [[Link Egypt]] at 12:17 am, [[Etisalat Misr]] at 12:19 am, and [[Internet Egypt]] at 12:25 am.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Renesys interpreted the shutdown as people getting phone calls one at a time, telling them to take themselves off the air, rather than an automated system taking all providers down at once.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Facebook confirmed a decrease in traffic from Egypt.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-54463420110127|title=Facebook Says Has Seen Drop in Traffic from Egypt|work=[[Reuters]]|author=Oreskovic, Alexei; Chiacu, Doina|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> A [[Border Gateway Protocol]] monitoring site in [[Vancouver, Canada]], reported most of the primary AS (ISPs) dropping a large percentage if not all of route advertisements.<ref>{{Verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason=what are credentials of source of this citation? blog sponsor - "bgpmon.net" seemingly has no Wikipedia article}} {{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://bgpmon.net/blog/?p=450|title=Internet in Egypt Offline|publisher=[[bgpmon.net]]|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> Virtually all of Egypt's Internet addresses were unreachable, worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kanalley, Craig|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/egypt-internet-goes-down-_n_815156.html |title=Egypt's Internet Shut Down, According to Reports |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> In response, Egyptians used [[smartphone]]s as modems, and even [[land line]]s with [[dial-up modem]]s to make international calls to access the internet, fax machines in universities and embassies, and [[ham radio]] to circumvent the restrictions. Furthermore, the sole remaining functioning ISP, Noor, which had had eight percent of the market share in Egypt (but which connected the Egyptian stock market and many western companies to the outside world<ref>[[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-12322948 "Old Technology Finds Role in Egyptian Protests"]. ''[[BBC News]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>), has been reported by [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]], an [[anonymity network]], on 30 January to be the source of a quadrupling of Tor clients from Egypt within twenty-four hours as of 30 January;<ref>Gohring, Nancy; McMillan, Robert (29 January 2011). [http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/374857/without_internet_egyptians_find_new_ways_get_online "Without Internet, Egyptians Find New Ways To Get Online â People Around the World are Offering Dial-Up Modem Numbers and Other Primitive Tools for People in Egypt"]. ''[[IDG|IDG News]]'' (via ''[[Computerworld]]''). Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> the use of Tor has sky-rocketed due to the situation in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/recent-events-egypt |title=Recent Events in Egypt|publisher=[[Blog]] of [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/local/local-company-helps-give-egyptians-internet-access-20110130 |title=Local company helps give Egyptians internet access |publisher=Myfoxboston.com |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
In response to the shut-down of the various media, the U.S. State Department spokesman [[Philip Crowley]] said that open communications must be allowed.<ref name="bloomberg1"/> About 24 hours after the blackout began, cellphone and smartphone e-mail access were restored, including Vodafone and Mobinil, though internet access was reportedly still down.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hendawi, Hamza; Michael, Maggie|url=http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-general/20110128/ML.Egypt.Protest/|title= Egyptian Reform Leader Calls for Mubarak To Resign |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via [[Comcast]])|date=2011-01-31|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
Noting the monopoly of pro-government medias downgrading the movement, ignoring it, and leading a smear campaign, the young activists reacted. A Facebook page was set up to provide a pro-protest view of the movement on the Tahriq square, his pacific approach, and aims. A team of 20 antigovernment activists rotated to pusblish online articles, a copy-cat of the state-owned newspaper was publish with pro-protest headlines, and a pirate radio station streamed over the internet.<ref>{{citation|last1=Fahim|first1=Kareem|last2=El-Naggar|first2=Mona|date=2011-02-08|publisher=The New York Times|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09ghonim.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=Mona El-Nagger&st=cse}}</ref>
On 31 January, [[Google]] and Twitter launched the [[Speak To Tweet]] service that allowed people caught up in the unrest to post [[voicemail]] messages via Twitter without any access to the internet.<ref name="Google Blog">{{cite web|last=Singh|first=Ujjwal|title=Some weekend work that will (hopefully) allow more Egyptians to be heard|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/01/some-weekend-work-that-will-hopefully.html|publisher=Google|accessdate=3 May 2011}}</ref><ref name="speak2tweet">[http://twitter.com/speak2tweet speak2tweet] on [[Twitter]]<br />some translations at [http://egypt.alive.in alive in egypt]</ref> Despite a low usage of Twitter in the country (there are some 14,000 Twitter users in Egypt, according to the social media firm [[Sysomos]],<ref>{{Verify credibility|date=February 2011|reason=what is notablility of this "blog" whose sponsor "symosos" seemingly has no Wikipedia article?}} {{cite web|author=Evans, Mark|url=http://blog.sysomos.com/2011/01/31/egyptian-crisis-twitte/|title=Egyptian Crisis: The Revolution Will Not Be Tweeted|publisher=[[blog]] of [[Symosos]]|date=2011-01-31|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>) Twitter organised a new account @twitterglobalpr in reference specifically to Egypt's use of the tool<ref>{{cite web|author=Hopkins, Curt|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/twitter_blocked_in_egypt.php|title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt in Response to Massive Protests (Updated)|publisher=''[[ReadWriteWeb]]'' ([[blog]])|date=2011-01-25|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> after it was blocked on 25 January.<ref>SG (Sean Garrett) (25 January ''[2011]''). [http://twitter.com/#!/twitterglobalpr/status/30063209247408128 "We can confirm that Twitter was blocked in Egypt around 8 am PT today. It is impacting both Twitter.com & applications. (1/2)."] Sean Garrett (via [[Twitter]]). Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
On 2 February, Internet access was restored in a staggered fashion much as it had been withdrawn.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/02/egypt-returns-to-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Returns To The Internet - Renesys Blog |publisher=Renesys.com |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Initial estimates by the [[OECD]] and [[Forbes]] magazine of the costs of the shut-down to Egypt's telecom sector alone range from $90M to $110M (with the higher figure factoring in the exodus of [[call center]]s); the impact on the country's wider tourism industry was estimated to be "at least $1B." <ref>{{cite web|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/02/egypt-off-switch/ |title=Report: Egypt Shut Down Net With Big Switch, Not Phone Calls | Threat Level |publisher=Wired.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
===Arrests, harassment, and assault of foreign journalists and NGOs=== [[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak unplugging Egypt from the Internet, and about to be disconnected himself in turn]] On 3 February, journalists from a number of news organisations, including CNN, the Associated Press, CBS News, BBC News, Al Jazeera English, Danish TV2 News, Swiss television, Swedish [[SVT]] and Belgium's ''Le Soir'' newspaper, were reported assaulted, detained or otherwise obstructed.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} <!--<ref name="WSJ-journalists"/> this ref name was most likely orphaned during one of the upmteem drafts; possibly a section ported from main article? needs some research. hidden for now, (added cite tag) to avoid the ugly red message in citations-->The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] said, on 3 February, that Mubarak had "unleashed an unprecedented and systematic attack on international media."<ref name="CPJ-3Feb">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/mubarak-intensifies-press-attacks-with-assaults-de.php|title=Mubarak Intensifies Press Attacks with Assaults, Detentions|date=2011-02-03|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> Security forces and pro-government gangs "hunted down journalists in their offices and hotels", preventing broadcast networks from airing live footage from Tahrir Square.<ref name="Kirkpatrick-journlists">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04journalists.html|title=Reporters in Egypt Under Broad Assault|author=Kirkpatrick, David D.; Goodman, J. David|date=2011-02-04|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
Armed Mubarak supporters attacked foreign journalists, physically, and by smashing their equipment. Plainclothes police officers were alleged to have shut down news media outlets that had been operating in buildings overlooking the square. Mubarak supporters also seized an informal center set up by human rights workers in the square, and, according to [[Amnesty International]], two of their employees and one from [[Human Rights Watch]] were detained.
Two other ''Al Jazeera'' reporters were also attacked as they arrived from the airport.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/new-clashes-as-egypt-protesters-push-back-rivals-1.756374 |title=Egypt VP Says Violence Result of 'Conspiracy' â Clashes Between Opponents, Partisans of Mubarak Rage for Second Day |work=[[Gulf News]] |date=2011-02-03|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> As of 9 February, almost 12 ''Al Jazeera'' reporters had been arrested.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gregg Carlstrom |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/02/201128184630458723.html |title=Hazards of reporting from Egypt - Features |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Two reporters working for ''[[The New York Times]]'' were released after being detained overnight in Cairo. Two ''[[Washington Post]]'' staffers were among two-dozen journalists detained by the Interior Ministry on Thursday morning, the paper reported. The White House spokesman, [[Robert Gibbs]], condemned the Mubarak government's harassment of journalists, calling it "completely and totally unacceptable", and that "any journalist that has been detained should be released immediately".<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04egypt.html?_r=1&partner=rss&emc=rss&src=igw "Crackdown in Egypt Widens to Foreign Observers"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 3 February 2011.</ref>
Swedish media reported that SVT (Swedish national television) reporter Bert SundstrÃ¶m was arrested while covering events in Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]].<ref name="thelocal1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.se/31826/20110203/|title=Swedish Reporter Stabbed in Cairo|work=[[The Local]]|author=[[Staff writer]]|date=2011-02-03|accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> Later the same day, on 3 February, Swedish media reported that SundstrÃ¶m had undone surgery in a Cairo hospital after suffering knife injuries to his stomach and back and head injuries.<ref name="thelocal1"/><ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=article in swedish. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended next to swedish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (4 February 2011). [http://www.expressen.se/nyheter/1.2316540/svt-s-bert-sundstrom-forsvunnen-i-kairo "SVT:s Bert SundstrÃ¶m svÃ¥rt knivskuren i Kairo"] (in [[Swedish language|Swedish]]). ''[[Expressen]]''. Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Two reporters from ''[[Aftonbladet]]'' were also detained for several hours having been accused of being [[Mossad]] spies,<ref name="jpost1"/> and a four-member news team from [[Israel]] were detained and later released.<ref name="jpost1">{{cite web|author=Klein, Herb |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=206464 |title=4 Israeli Journalists Arrested, Then Released in Cairo |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
CNN correspondent [[Anderson Cooper]] and his news crew were roughed up by a pro-Mubarak mob, and reporters from the ''[[Washington Post]]'' were harassed.<ref name="jpost1"/> Cooper was reportedly punched in the head 10 times.<ref name="jpost1"/> A journalist for [[Dubai]]-based [[Al-Arabiya]] television reportedly suffered concussion after being attacked.<ref name="jpost1"/> Six Al Jazeera journalists were arrested on 1 February before being released a few hours later.<ref name="jpost1"/>
According to ''[[Aftonbladet]]'', a [[Greece|Greek]] photographer was also stabbed in the leg.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=article in swedish. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended next to swedish headline}} Sundell, Camilla (3 February 2011). [http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article8510828.ab "Bert SundstrÃ¶m allvarligt skadad"] (in [[Swedish language|Swedish]]). ''[[Aftonbladet]]''. Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref>
The Committee to Protect Journalists said that it was looking into at least ten cases of journalists who had been detained in Cairo since 2 February.<ref name="thelocal1"/>
By the evening of 3 February, in Cairo, no major broadcaster was able to air live coverage from the square, the epicenter of the protests.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04journalists.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&src=ig "Gangs Hunt Journalists and Rights Workers"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 3 February 2011.</ref>
The next day, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (France)|French Foreign Ministry]] said it had had no word about the fate of three French journalists who work for ''[[Le Figaro]]'' and were kidnapped by unidentfied assailants.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.journalists/ "Journalists Have 'Full Freedom' in Egypt, Prime Minister Says"]. ''[[CNN]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
On February 15, CBS News reported<ref>{{cite news|author=Font size Print E-mail Share |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/15/60minutes/main20032070.shtml?tag=contentMain;contentBody |title=CBS News' Lara Logan Assaulted During Egypt Protests - 60 Minutes |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> that its chief foreign correspondent, [[Lara Logan]], had been assaulted on February 11, by a frenzied mob of Egyptian protesters. She was abruptly separated from her crew, after which she suffered a brutal 20-30 minute beating and sexual assault, before being rescued by a group of Egyptian women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers. She was taken to an American hospital, from which she was released on February 16, to recover in her Washington D.C. home. President Obama called her to express his concern. On February 17, Washington Post columnist Jonathan Capehart reported that there was no coverage of this assault from [[Al-Jazeera]]. Journalist [[Nir Rosen]] made insensitive and offensive comments about the attack on his Twitter page, and resigned shortly afterward, with apologies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=http://www.npr.org/2011/02/17/133822875/nyu-fellow-quits-after-tweets-about-logan-assault |title=NYU Fellow Quits After Tweets About Lara Logan Assault |publisher=NPR |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
==Financial markets== Although there are not many [[oil reserves]] in Egypt, Western governments are still very concerned about how commercial and economic stability will be affected by an unstable Egypt. The Suez Canal is one of the largest shipping arteries for [[crude oil]], and [[shipping lanes]] for trade.<ref name="Suez Canal and Price of Gas">Hall, Colby (28 January 2011). [http://www.mediaite.com/online/u-s-concern-over-egyptian-uprising-control-of-suez-canal-and-the-price-of-gas/ "Unspoken Concern Over Egyptian Uprising: Control Of Suez Canal And Price Of Gas"]. ''[[Mediaite]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
On 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html|title=Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=2011-01-16|accessdate=2011-02-01|author=Namatalla, Ahmed A.}}</ref> The EGX30 has dropped almost 1,000 points since 13 January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1 percent on 26 January, and then another 6.2 percent on 27 January, before the chief of the stock market temporarily suspended trading<ref>{{cite news|author=Farouk Ehab; Pfeiffer, Tom|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Update 1 â Egypt Bourse Suspends Trade after Index Slides |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> due to marked losses in the first minutes of the opening session. The stock index closed the day down by 10.5 percent.<ref>{{cite news|last=Halzack |first=Sarah |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-economy/2011/01/riots_in_egypt_weigh_heavily_o.html |title=Egypt Riots Weigh on the Nation's Stock Market |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2010-01-28 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> On the first trading day in the week following the expansion of protests the EGX again fell.<ref name="bloomberg3feb"/>
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] reduced Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Orders Egyptian Army to Aid Police as Protests Against Rule Widen|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|author=Salama, Vivian; Galal, Ola; Alexander, Caroline}}</ref> They also suggested that they may cut the national credit rating.<ref name="bloombergclose">Haroutunian, Mourad; Namatalla, Ahmed A. (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/egyptian-bourse-banks-will-be-closed-today-state-tv-reports.html "Egyptian Bourse, Banks Will Stay Closed Today After Anti-Mubarak Protests"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Stocks Drop Worldwide as Oil, Dollar Surge After Egypt Protests|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|author=Nazareth, Rita; Hwang, Inyoung |date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> On 30 January, Deputy Central Bank Governor Hisham Ramez said that the interbank market will "be a liquid market" when it opens after law and order is restored.<ref>Shahine, Alaa (30 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/interbank-market-in-egypt-to-be-liquid-when-activity-resumes-ramez-says.html "Egypt's Interbank Market Will Be 'Liquid' When Operations Resume"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
On 1 February, the [[financial services|financial-services]] company [[HSBC]] upgraded Egyptian bonds from hold to buy, after they were put up from sale four days before.{{clarify|date=February 2011}}<!--the last 5 words don't make sense--> They said the bonds could be very cheap after the fall.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of german headline appended next to german headline}} [[Staff writer]] (1 February 2011). [http://www.ftd.de/politik/international/:aufstand-am-nil-us-botschafterin-trifft-el-baradei/60006042.html "Mubarak legt Datum fÃ¼r AmtsÃ¼bergabe fest (16:45 Uhr)"] (in [[German language|German]]). ''[[Financial Times Deutschland]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> On 2 February, Egyptian ten-year, dollar-denominated bond yields rose 6.52 percent, following a record 7.21 percent on 31 January.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (2 February 2011). [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/02/02/bloomberg1376-LFZGRH0YHQ0X01-7RSL1N3SMHJNFE47GDFPD79OG5.DTL#ixzz1Ctr6JDcj "Mubarak Fails To Quell Protests as Turmoil Spreads to Yemen"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' (via ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''). Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
On 8 February, Egyptâs credit risk fell to the lowest and least riskiest level since the protests began. Egyptian sovereign debt bond yield decreased by .32%. A bond auction on 7 February met most of the 15 billion Egyptian pounds (US$2.5 billion) sought as business leader and participany in government-opposition talks Naguib Sawiris said there had been "big progress."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Camilla |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-07/egyptian-credit-risk-falling-to-lowest-since-protests-started.html |title=Egypt Credit Risk Falls to Lowest Since Start of Protests as Crisis Eases |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> The Deputy Central Bank Governor Hisham Ramez said that the central bank would support the Egyptian pount from fluctuations after the currency fell 1.6% to a six-year low against the US dollar. "We saw excessive speculative activity so we intervened to stabilise the market." Though the pound gained most of its losses forwards contracts reflected a 4.9% weakening in three months.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-08/egyptian-central-bank-intervenes-to-support-currency-deputy-governor-says.html |title=Egyptian Pound Gains the Most Since November as Central Bank `Intervenes' |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
On 10 February, amid rumours of Mubarak stepping down dollar-denomitaed bonds strengthend, as did Egyptian [[global depository receipts]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Martin |first=Eric |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/egypt-bonds-rebound-gdrs-pare-losses-after-reports-mubarak-may-step-down.html |title=Egypt ETF Pares Gain on Mubarak Plan to Remain President, Delegate Power |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
===Regional markets=== On 29 January, Saudi Arabia's [[Tadawul]] stock market index fell 6.4 percent, the most since 25 May 2010, on concern over Egypt's instability.<ref>{{cite web|last=Haroutunian |first=Mourad |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-29/saudi-arabian-stocks-tumble-most-in-eight-months-as-egyptians-defy-curfew.html |title=Saudi Arabian Stocks Tumble Most in Eight Months as Egyptians Defy Curfew |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
On 30 January, the [[Dubai Financial Market]]'s General Index also fell 6.2 percent (the most since December 2009) during mid-day trading on concern "international investors are fleeing Middle East stock markets with justified risk aversion across the board." The Tadawul rebounded somewhat from the previous days crash, but Qatar's QE Index fell 3 percent, the most since 25 May and Abu Dhabi's ADX General Index also fell 3.7 percent. Kuwait's SE Price Index fell a narrower 1.8 percent, Oman's MSM30 fell 3 percent and Bahrain's All Share Index also fell a narrower 1.4 percent. Meanwhile, Israel's TA-25 Index fell almost 2.5 percent, the most since May 2010 as [[Ampal-American Israel Corporation]], who own a stake in Egypt's [[East Mediterranean Gas Company]], fell by the most in nearly two years. Israeli government ten-year-bond yields rose.<ref>{{cite news|author=Hankir, Zahra|date=2011-01-30|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/dubai-shares-plunge-most-in-year-lead-gulf-drop-on-egypt-risk-protests.html|title=Dubai Shares Fall Most Since May on Egypt Unrest, Pacing Mideast Decline|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref>
===Global markets=== In the first days of the protests, international gold prices jumped more than US$20 â the most in twelve weeks â to US$1,341.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tian, Yi; Nguyen, Pham-Duy |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html |title=Gold Jumps Most in 12 Weeks on Haven Demand Amid Egypt Tensions |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> The price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3 percent) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite web|last=Habiby |first=Margot |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html |title=Crude Oil Surges the Most Since 2009 on Concern Egyptian Unrest to Spread |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=2008-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
On 31 January, major European and Asian markets continued their fall from 28 January due to Egyptian unrest.<ref>Haigh, Adam (31 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-31/stocks-fall-in-europe-on-egyptian-protests-thomas-cook-fiat-shares-drop.html "Most European Stocks Drop; Lufthansa, Air France Fall as Greene King Gains"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> The Hungarian stock index [[BUX]] fell to its lowest in two weeks as the protests reduced investors' appetite for emerging-market assets.<ref>Gergely, Andras (31 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-31/hungarian-stocks-fall-to-two-week-low-forint-weakens-on-egypt.html "Hungarian Stocks Decline to Two-Week Low on Egyptian Protests"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
On 2 February, [[brent crude]] crossed US$100 on concern over instability.<ref>Lawler, Alex (4 February 2011). [http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Brent-oil-tops-103-on-Egypt-violence-Yemen-2011-02-03T114224Z-UPDATE-6 "Brent Oil Tops $103 on Egypt Violence, Yemen-Update 6"]. ''[[Forexyard]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref> The next day, crude oil advanced for the fifth day in a row on stability concerns amidst expanding protests in the Arab world.<ref name="bloomberg3feb">Kirkland, Stephen (3 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/japanese-stocks-decline-on-earnings-unrest-in-egypt-crude-copper-climb.html "Oil Climbs on Egypt as Stocks Decline; Copper Hits $10,000"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref> Rising oil prices as a result of the instability were reported to be pressuring [[OPEC]] to increase supplies in order to ease prices.<ref>Smith, Grant (4 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/egyptian-riots-add-pressure-on-opec-as-crude-exceeds-100-energy-markets.html "Egypt Riots Add Pressure on OPEC With $100 Oil: Energy Markets"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
On 4 February, [[Minister of Energy and Petroleum (Venezuela)|Venezuelan Energy Minister]] [[Rafael RamÃ­rez (Venezuela)|Rafael RamÃ­rez]] said that OPEC would only meet if the [[Suez Canal]] was shut and that the price of oil was rising to a "fair price".<ref>Skenk, Mark (4 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/crude-oil-increases-on-decline-in-u-s-unemployment-rate-unrest-in-egypt.html "Oil Falls as U.S. Adds Fewer Jobs Than Forecast, Fuel Use Drops"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
==Mubarak's family== [[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's sonâwho has been widely tipped as his successorâwas reported by the U.S.-based Arabic website [[Akhbar al-Arab]] to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|author=Jacob, Jijo |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the End' for Egypt's Mubarak as Son and Wife Flee|accessdate=2011-02-01|date=2011-01-26|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite news|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt|work=[[CBS News]] |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> An ''Al Jazeera'' reporter said that Gamal remained{{when|date=February 2011}} in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post â Police Post in City of Suez Burnt Down as Angry Protests Continue To Erupt Despite Security Crackdown|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> On 25 January, the ''[[International Business Times]]'' reported a traceless rumour on [[Twitter]] that the Egyptian President's wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]] has left for London as well.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/104960/20110125/suzanne-mubarak-of-egypt-has-fled-to-heathrow-airport-in-london-unconfirmed-reports.htm|title=Suzanne Mubarak of Egypt Has Fled to Heathrow Airport in London â Unconfirmed Reports|accessdate=2011-02-01|date=2011-01-25|work=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> On 29 January, it was reported that ''BBC Arabic'' had been told that Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak]] had arrived in London with their respective families.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five">{{cite news|author=Bhatty, Ayesha; Hirsturl, Michael|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/9380534.stm |title=As It Happened: Egypt Unrest Day Five |work=[[BBC News]] |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> Egyptian State Television has denied this report.<ref name="bbcnews egypt unrest day five"/><!-- This could also use a less-transient source --> ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' reported an unconfirmed rumour that Mubarak was planning a "prolonged hospital stay" in Germany, a move that would, in effect, have him leave the presidency paving the way for a face saving transition of power.<ref>[http://slatest.slate.com/id/2284189/ Der Spiegel: Mubarak Planning 'Hospital Stay' in Germany], The Slatest, 7 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/popups/popup_single_mediaplayer/0,,14824659_type_audio_struct_1429_contentId_14820842,00.html |title=Mubarak may travel to Germany for treatment (07.02.2010) |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
==National Dialogue== <!--although this small section can go on the main page--> Suleiman was ordered{{when|date=February 2011|reason=needs context (i.e., date}} by Mubarak to conduct negotiations with opposition groups.
Among the major ideas circulated was a compromise in which Suleiman would be delegated all of Mubarak's authorities for an interim period and Mubarak would stay on as an [[emeritus|honourary]] president for that period.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://www.hindustantimes.com/Suleiman-mulling-figurehead-role-for-Mubarak/Article1-658783.aspx "Suleiman Mulling Figurehead Role for Mubarak"]. ''[[Press Trust of India]]'' (via ''[[Hindustan Times]]''). 6 February 2011.</ref>
